item.description:
Hike Portland's East Prom Trail. Eat at Gritty McDuff's BrewPub. Walk around Old Port... A great Portland day!!

Portland, Maine's Eastern Promenade trail winds around the city's waterfront with views of islands, bays, and passing ships.

Its paved length runs for about 2 miles in each direction, allowing for a 3-4 mile roundtrip. 


After our walk, we'll head for lunch at Gritty McDuff's Brewpub for Red Claw Ale-battered Fish & Chips, or Shepherd's Pie marinated in Black Fly Stout. Or choose from beef, lamb, turkey & veggie burgers with a pint of their Best Bitter, the traditional English-style ale that was first brewed at Gritty's way back in 1988.

And once our hunger and thirsts are sated, we'll check out Old Port section of Portland and probably find some music.

Portsmouth Carpool: 9:50am. Portsmouth Bus Station - 185 Grafton Ave. There are two parking lots. Meet in the back of the overflow lot - the lot farthest from the main bus terminal building, farther up Grafton Ave. Meet at the very back of the lot.

Newburyport Carpool: 9:20am. C&J Bus lot, 90 Storey Ave/Rt 113 at I-95. (Post a comment if you want to meet here so others can see it.)

*Don't forget to share driving expenses.

Portland is Maine's largest city, and the 2.1-mile Eastern Promenade Trail along Casco Bay offers an ideal introduction to this coastal town and its trail network. 
The 'East Prom' begins in Old Port, a charming waterfront district with cobblestone streets and working piers. A massive brick foundry that once turned out steam engines now houses the trailside Maine Narrow Gauge Railroad Company & Museum. Outside, cheerfully restored narrow gauge train cars-including a bright red Ocean Spray boxcar-stand ready for service. For a nostalgic lark, take an out-and-back excursion on the slender railcars (narrow gauge rails stand just 2 feet apart). You'll skirt most of the trail's route. 
Take the side path up to Fort Allen Park to search for a battleship cannon, or stay on the trail and look southeast to spot Fort Gorges, which was armed and active during the Civil and Spanish-American wars. You'll reach the trail midpoint at East End Beach, where all-weather kayakers launch into the surf. 
From here, Eastern Promenade Park flanks the trail for a mile. Near the north end of the park, the rail-trail detours from the rail corridor up a short hill. From its rise, scan the bay for the remains of an old swing bridge that extends a third of a mile over the water. This majestic span was once part of the Grand Trunk Railway between Quebec and Maine. (From which the band, Grand Funk Railroad, got its name.)
At the crest of the hill, just past a colorful mural, the rail-trail nears its end. From here, you can backtrack to Old Port or continue along the Back Cove Loop Trail. 

Liability Release

AS A CONDITION OF ATTENDING THIS MEETUP, YOU AGREE TO hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer and his heirs, and all members and participants of the Seacoast Outdoors Meetup group from any and all claims for injury, illness, death, and/or property damage including those caused by negligence, ignorance, inexperience and other reasons. You also agree to assume all mental, physical, financial, and/or other risk associated with this meetup. Kayaking, camping, hiking, bicycling, snow sports, alcohol consumption, and other activities pose inherent risks and dangers. Participation in these activities is voluntary and dependent upon your own personal judgment.

 Your RSVP indicates consent to the refund policy.

Time and location are subject to change due to weather and other factors.  Always check email & this listing for updates before leaving home.
item.name: East Prom Trail, a Pub, & No Petunias!!
